title: How to Support Someone With Sickle Cell Disease as a Caregiver

content: When a sickle cell crisis takes over, I am in a very vulnerable state of dependence on others. Thankfully, my support network plays a pivotal role in advocating for me when I'm in pain and unable to communicate. Additionally, they care for me during my recovery. Without my support network, I wouldn't be here today.

Receiving support from anyone outside my immediate family hasn't always been easy for me to do. I have felt embarrassed, ashamed, or angry when needing to ask for help because of an underlying desire not to be seen as weak or helpless.

At this stage of my growth, I welcome support. However, certain conditions improve how I receive support from a caregiver/support network. I must know them well enough to feel comfortable in my vulnerability. They must also recognize that I can't communicate very well when I'm in pain. They're not allowed to treat me with pity. And they must understand that sometimes, just being present is enough.

content: How does one ensure these conditions are met with an unpredictable disease like sickle cell? I wish I had the answer, but these are examples of my quirky support needs. I sometimes prefer to be left alone when these needs are unmet.

In those instances, no help is better than help that isn't genuine or needed. As a caregiver or as part of someone's support network with sickle cell, it's essential to understand the person and what they need. What works for me may not work for another person, so it's always important to discuss how the caregiver can support you best.

Ask what your loved one wants or needs before a sickle cell crisis happens. One thing I can guarantee is that it's hard to communicate when experiencing so much pain. To remedy this, I advise you to devise a crisis plan and discuss the possible scenarios to ensure you know what they need beforehand. Request a copy of their protocol/treatment plan when in the hospital to use as a guide if they are in a different hospital than usual.

content: Establish what different pain scores mean for your loved one with sickle cell and which number means it's time to go to the hospital. For example, if my pain score is at 5 or below on a scale of 1 to 10, I can manage at home. At 6 or 7, I should consider going to the hospital. A score of 8 or above will require me to be admitted.

Easy access to treatment can be crucial in reducing the event's duration, and other supplies can help keep them comfortable. Most of my crises happen at night when I'm at home and can easily access my medications and comfort items. However, the unpredictable nature of crises means they can happen anywhere, so it's essential to be prepared. As a caregiver, consider how easily you can access that person’s medications, hot water bottles, fluids, or anything else they may need during a crisis.

When I think about my experience, I realize that my family had to learn from each crisis. Each one taught them a new lesson that would have been great to know beforehand. Caregivers with fewer years of experience than my family will initially need help with what to do. Nothing prepares you for witnessing a loved one in pain, but with a plan, you have a better chance of taking the proper steps.

sections.heading: During a Crisis
content: If you don't have a plan for when a crisis happens, the most important thing to do is to make sure your loved one is comfortable. Ensure the person in crisis has the basics: food, water, and medication. Also, make sure they are warm enough. It's essential to be mindful that when experiencing a crisis, people are hypersensitive to temperatures.

Check in frequently with your loved one or patient about their pain level. Ask them about the intensity and location of the pain. They will know best how they're feeling, so engaging with them is vital. However, they may get irritated by frequent questioning, so try to space it out or only ask when their discomfort becomes more visible.

content: It can be uncomfortable to see a loved one in so much pain. The quick transition from self-sufficiency to dependence can be shocking to witness. When caring for them, try not to pity them and ask only questions with yes or no responses. What helped me during my last crisis was being given autonomy over my care despite not being the best communicator.

sections.heading: After a Crisis
content: Recovering from a crisis looks different for everyone. It will take a person longer to heal if they experience any traumatic events at the hospital. Recovery from a crisis isn't complete once the pain has stopped or a patient has been released from the hospital. It takes a while to return to optimal health, so be patient and supportive. During the recovery stage, gauging your patient or loved one’s mobility and mental well-being can be challenging. They will become more autonomous daily, but finding balance is essential. Therefore, talk with your loved one about how you can aid in their recovery.

Once recovery has happened, both the caregiver and the patient should have a debrief about what happened. This conversation can build upon plans made and check in emotionally regarding how both parties feel. Preparing with a game plan will make things easier.
